citation.article-title: Anaerobic degradation of aniline and dihydroxybenzenes by newly isolated sulfate-reducing bacteria and description of Desulfobacterium anilini.

p.s: Desulfobacterium anilini (ani.li'ni. M.L. adj. anilini pertaining to aniline (aminobenzene). Desulfobaeterium anilini: a sulfate-reducing bacterium oxidizing aniline)
Cells rod-shaped, 1.25 μm wide and 1.5-3 μm long.
Chemoorganotrophic, sulfate or sulfite serve as electron acceptors, elemental sulfur or nitrate not used.
Thiosulfate can be dismutated to sulfate and sulfide, without growth.

Substrates used are aniline, phenol, p-cresol, several hydroxy- and aminobenzoates, indolylacetate, formate, acetate, higher fatty acids up to stearate, pyruvate, cyclohexanol, cyclohexanone, cyclohexane carboxylate.
Most substrates completely oxidized to CO2 via the CO-dehydrogenase pathway.
Addition of vitamin B12 and thiamine as growth factors and dithionite 100-200 μM as reducing agent necessary.
Growth in freshwater and salt water medium.
Optimal salt concentrations: 14 g NaCl/l and 2 g MgCl x 6 H2O/l. pH-optimum around 6.9-7.5; temperatnre optimum at 35°C.
Cells contain cytochrome c and sulfite reductase P 582, no desulfoviridin.
DNA base ratio: 59.1 mol% G + C (thermal denaturation).
D. anilini has been enriched and isolated so far only from marine sediments.
Type strain: Anti, DSM 4660, deposited with the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen, Braunschweig.
